body:
Thanks for the report. This should be an easy fix and we'll fix it before the next release.

To prevent this in the future, we should test against the lowest supported version of each dependency. Is there an existing tool that can do that?

I am not aware of such a tool. A hacky way (that would create more work for maintainers) would be to just make a requirements_minimum.txt and use that maybe on one Ubuntu CI job. The action would just need to install those pinned versions before installing black and we run our CI suite and maybe integration tests with diff shades/primer to find errors like this reported behavior.

issue.title: Run tests with minimum versions of dependencies installed

labels.name: C: maintenance
labels.description: Related to project maintenance, e.g. CI, testing, policy changes, releases

issue.body:
Follow-up from #2791 and https://github.com/psf/black/issues/2774, we should add a step to the test workflow which runs the test suite again but with the lowest supported dependencies installed. Unfortunately there doesn't really seem to be good tooling for this (short of https://github.com/ffy00/python-resolver#mindeps-cli) so this may be blocked until such tooling exists or we could take the cheap to implement / more expensive down the road route of defining a constraints file that manually pins the dependencies to the lowest versions supported.

We could run diff-shades/primer against the minimum dependencies but I'm wary of the CI time increases. Especially as it's unlikely an older version of a dependency would cause a subtle issue with formatting (given the core formatting logic is all our own) that these sorts of jobs discover.

body:
Forcing click>=8.0.0 on users for a dev dependency is pretty harsh. There are MANY application dependencies that are still locked to <=7.1.2.

Due to this I can't upgrade from the latest Black beta release.

I agree, but unfortunately, we do break with < click 8.0.0 and that breaks people and causes issue reports.

[Python Virtual environments](https://docs.python.org/3/tutorial/venv.html) could assist you here, but I have worked in large shared dependency environments and have felt your pain. I am sorry for that. Unfortunately the only other option is to bring your other CLIs in the same environment to >= click 8.0.0 that share dependencies with black.

issue.title: APPSRE-4354 black formatter

repository.name: qontract-reconcile
repository.description: CLI tool to reconcile services with their desired state as defined in App-Interface

issue.body:
**Background**

The team overall agreed to use the black code formatter. This PR is an initial migration towards black. The black formatter is only executed on files which are considered stable (i.e., haven't been changed in 30 days) 

**Change**

- add black configuration
- use black proposed line-length default of 88
- Black formatting on .py files which haven't been changed in the last 30 days according to `git log`
- change test order to lint -> type -> py39
- add dedicated `requirements/` directory to cluster all `requirements-*.txt` files

**Open Issues**

The [first stable release](https://github.com/psf/black/releases/tag/22.1.0) of [black requires `click>=8`](https://github.com/psf/black/issues/2774). We require `click<8.0` in our setup.py. For now, we would be stuck with [previous release](https://github.com/psf/black/releases/tag/21.12b0) until we bump click to >=8. Running `[black 22.1] black --check` did not raise any issues on the formatting of the previous version in this PR. So chances are that a later bump will be unproblematic.

A follow-up ticket was created to address this. The ticket is linked to the current ticket.

**Reviewer Notes**

This PR makes substantial changes to the code base, i.e., a lot of revert/squash/rebases are necessary to keep up-to-date with master.
To keep things easy: 
1. The first commit in this PR contains all configuration aspects
2. The second commit contains changes from running the formatter.

body: Hi, Will this be back ported to `22.1.0` or is it gonna be a new release version? If later, when can we expect the changes in PyPI.
I'm pretty sure this is fixed in 22.1.0: https://github.com/psf/black/blob/main/CHANGES.md#packaging-1
I still see the error for black 22.1.0 where click is installed as 7.1.2. Do I have to lock black with "21.12b0" till this issue is fixed?? Please let me know

>

This didn't fix the problem.

I still got the problem with:

python: ```3.7```
black: ```22.1.0```
click: ```8.0.4```

```Traceback (most recent call last):
File "/usr/local/bin/black", line 5, in <module>
   from black import patched_main
File "src/black/__init__.py", line 35, in <module>
ImportError: cannot import name 'ParameterSource' from 'click.core' (/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/click/core.py)

Can this issue be reopened?  Same error with latest black 22.3.0 and python 3.8.  If ParameterSource is not available in click core, could black downgrade gracefully?  Some dependent packages using click which are not under control.
@asears Can you specify what this "similar issue" is? What versions are you running and what error are you getting?
